div.head:
Embleme 18. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Fire loves to burne, not to aurify, but gold.

lg.l: All Natures agents doe their seed diffuse,
That thus they may their species produce:
Soe fire makes all things fire, nor ever was
A true effect without its proper cause:
Gold generates noe fire, fire noe gold indeed;
All things are propagated by their seed.

div.head: Discourse 18.
div.ab:
Natures way of operating in all individualls of the universe is to use one
single processe to complete and perfect one single motion, as appears in the
Anatomy of mans body, in which one muscle serves onely for one motion,
that is, the attractive, but for the expansive another opposite to the first, soe
that if any part or member be to be brought into a circular forme, it must
be effected by various muscles placed circle=wise: soe the operation of fire
is one and single, that is to say, to heat and fire, yea assimilate to itselfe, and
burne all things, to which it is applyed, if they be combustible: Hereupon
Sayth Avicenne in his booke of the congelation of stones: That which falls into Salt
pitts, becomes Salt, and that which into fire, becomes fire, but somethings sooner,
some Slower, according to the power of atives , and the resisteme of passives: And
there is a place in Arabia, which coloureth all bodyes in it of its owne colour: Soe
every naturall thing possesseth the virtue infusd into it by nature, by which
it acts upon things mixd or applyed to it, assimilating and altering their nature
and forme: That which is generation in vegetables and animalls by the pro
pagation of seeds, is the infusion of virtue and assimilation in single bodyes
or singly mixd: the Sunne, the light of heaven, projects its rayes upon the
earth, which, being gathered together in concavous or burning glasses, doe demon
strate themselves to be produced from such a cause, as to appear to be the
projectible formes of the Sunne: Whereby it is manifest that the rayes of the
Sunne are nothing els, but a fiery flame extended and dispersed into an ample
latitude, which being dilated and againe contracted by concavous, diaphanous
and circular or repercussive instruments, doth in concavous and steele mirrors
Shine as a flame, and burne things obvious to it: after the same manner, a
certaine virtue is as a vapour dispersed in a certaine elemented body, which,
if it be gathered together, and attracted into one, turnes into water, and that
water into earth: For this reason sayth Avicenne in the booke before alleadged,
Earth is made of water, when the qualityes of earth overcome it, and soe on
the contrary: But there is a certaine thing, which some ingenious men doe
use when they have a mind to coagulate a dry substance, which is com
pounded of two waters, and is called Lac virginis, which is the most certaine
effect of it: this Sayth hee: Some arethere are that assure themselves
able to increase or multiply virtues in the Load=stone, as the like wee have
seen sett in Silver, which being scarce one pound weight attracted and held up an
iron anchor of 28 pounds, which would have been impossible, if the virtue
had not been increasd and made stronger in it, which without doubt was
done by revocation of the dispersed virtues as it were into one point or pole,
or by the attraction of the same out of a great body into a lesse: Others are
found, who say that a plumbifying Stone may be made by the Sulphurous
breath of Saturne, infused and retained, till it be thereby converted into
comon Mercury, which continually converts comon Mercury into lead.
Some boast that they can by Antimony, or the stellated Regulus there
of make Copper from the fume of Copper, in that time wherein a
man may eat an egge, yea that they have made all metalls: but
I will not detract from their reputation, though to mee it seems not
Discourse 18.
likely to be true: I know not whether they are more confident or
successefull, who endeavour to deduce gold from gold, according to the
saying of the golden poett: Hee that desires barley sowes onely barley,
in gold is the seed of gold: Every naturall thing hath indeed a certaine
virtue of multiplying itselfe, but these things are brought into action
in Vegetables and animalls onely, not at all in Metalls, Mineralls, things
dugge out of the earth, or Meteor: Some plants sprung from a small
graine of seed doe oftentimes yeild a thousand or more grains of seed,
and soe multiply and propagate themselves, and that yearly; Ani
malls allso have their products of greater or lesse number, according
to the nature of every one: But gold, Silver, lead, tinne, iron, copper, or
Argent vive are never found to have multiplyd themselves or their species
after that manner, though one may be very often found commuted and
nobilitated into another: Neverthelesse the Philosophers affirme that the
principle of ignifying is in fire, soe of aurifying in gold: but where is
the tincture, by which gold must be made? This must be sought in
its owne principles and generations, not in things of another nature: For
if fire produceth fire, a Pear, a horse a horse, then lead must
generate lead and not Silver, gold gold and not the tincture: Moreover
the Philosophers have a peculiar gold, which they doe not onely not
deny that it ought (but allso affirme it necessarily requisite) to be
added to the aurificke Stone as a ferment as the end of the worke. The
ferment, converting the thing fermented into its owne nature, without
which the whole composition would never come to perfection
